awd_titl_txt: Theory and Application of Some New Approaches to Electronically Non-Adiabatic Dynamic
awd_abstract_narration:
William H. Miller and Stephen J. Cotton of the University of California, Berkeley are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Chemistry Program in the Division of chemistry to develop theoretical methods for simulating a variety of molecular processes that are fundamental to many modern technologies.   These processes involve coupled electronic states.  Such simulations allow researchers to understand these processes more  deeply and thus be able to modify them in useful ways.      Examples are biomolecular processes, photovoltaic behavior, and photo-catalysis. The approach that Miller and Cotton is developing is characterized by its simplicity and its efficiency.  The goal is to have a reliable and easy to use approach for simulating larger and more complex molecular systems than is what is currently possible. 


The specific focus of this research is electronically non-adiabatic processes, i.e., those that involve transitions between different electronic states. The challenge is to treat the electronic degrees of freedom and the nuclear degrees of freedom, to which they are coupled, in a consistent framework.  The approach uses the Meyer-Miller (MM) model for the electronic degrees of freedom, which shows how they can be "mapped" onto harmonic oscillators, one for each electronic state. This then allows the use of classical molecular dynamics for electronics as well as nuclear degrees of freedom.  The MM model would be exact if all the degrees of freedom were treated quantum mechanically.    Treating them all classically is an approximation but can often be very accurate by using semiclassical ideas to "re-quantize" the electronic degrees of freedom  This has resulted in the development of a striking simple symmetrical quasi-classical (SQC) windowing procedure that provides a semiclassical-like "quantization" of the electronic oscillator degrees-of- freedom (DOF) in classical Meyer-Miller (MM) vibronic dynamics. Significant benchmarking of this SQC/MM approach has been seen to give semiclassical-like (and therefore quantum-like) results, but to do so orders of magnitude more efficiently than a true semiclassical calculation and, of course, without the inherent exponentially scaling cost of a full quantum dynamics simulation

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Theory and Application of some New Approaches to Electronically Non-Adiabatic Dynamics


Electronically non-adiabatic dynamical processes constitute a large and ubiquitous class of chemical phenomena which are core to many application domains of modern molecular science. Examples include artificial light-harvesting (solar power), nano-electronics, electronic energy storage (batteries), novel semiconductor materials, and, more broadly, any molecular system where the motion of atomic nuclei is strongly coupled to the dynamics of the electrons. In this view, it is an important task of modern chemical theory to provide computational tools capable of accurately modeling the intricate dynamical interplay between nuclei and the electrons. The goal, of course, is to have simulation tools for understanding and predicting non-adiabatic chemical reactivity and related material properties, and even to guide the design of new chemistries and/or materials from first principles. 

It is well understood that the accurate simulation of many non-trivial molecular systems is severely hampered by the fundamental fact that the rigorous quantum mechanical treatment of many quantum particles scales exponentially with particle number. Nowadays, it is anticipated that future quantum hardware-based computing will be helpful in addressing this deficiency, but a nevertheless practical and complementary strategy is to minimize quantum resource requirements in the first place by working to distinguish between what parts of a chemical problem actually require a quantum treatment and what parts don't (and act accordingly). In many cases, most of the chemical dynamics---i.e., the rearrangements of the nuclei---can be adequately handled by a simpler treatment based on classical (Newtonian) mechanics, which scales only linearly with the number of particles. 

One such classical model, which incorporates some quantum mechanical aspects while retaining the cost structure of classical mechanics, is that developed by Meyer and Miller to deal with the particular problem of coupled nuclear and electronic dynamics (i.e., nonadiabatics). Meyer and Miller (MM) showed that, despite the fact that electrons are lightweight quantum particles, when the electronic degrees of freedom are treated collectively as electronic "states," they may, in many cases, be adequately modeled as a set of classical harmonic oscillators. The question then becomes how to "quantize" these classical oscillators---how to put just enough quantum back into the model---and while a variety of approaches have been attempted, one fairly recent approach show to be simple and effective is the symmetrical quasiclassical (SQC) quantization developed by Cotton and Miller. 

In previous work, the SQC-quantized MM harmonic oscillator model was illustrated to be capable of effectively treating a variety of standard exemplar nonadiabatic systems. A goal of the present grant was to go a step further and to demonstrate the capabilities of the SQC/MM model in realistic scenarios where the aforementioned electronic states---the core inputs to the model---are determined by a quantum treatment of the electrons themselves via rigorous electronic structure theory. This was accomplished by first incorporating the SQC/MM model into the Q-Chem quantum chemistry software package (out of UC Berkeley) which is widely used in the computational chemistry community. First appearing in Version 6.1 and documented at https://manual.q-chem.com/latest/sect_MMND.html, Q-Chem provides the SQC/MM model with a rigorous "on-the-fly" calculation of the electronic configuration---i.e., the many electronic states---closely integrated software engineering-wise with the dynamics of the classical nuclei as computed via SQC/MM dynamics. Notably, this provides an avenue for the SQC/MM methodology to be used by many computational chemists, besides ourselves, interested in electronically non-adiabatic dynamics

With the Q-Chem-based computational framework in hand, several realistic systems were treated to illustrate the methodology and implementation. As an initial benchmark, the electronically non-adiabatic dynamics of sodium hydride (NaH) was modeled with the SQC/MM approach and it was shown to be in good agreement with what were essentially exact quantum calculations, calculations possible in this example because NaH is a diatom system. Moving to more complicated realistic systems, the electronic nonadiabatic dynamics of (i) excited-state intramolecular hydrogen-transfer in malonaldehyde (C3H4O2) and (ii) light-activated ring-opening/ring-puckering dynamics in selenophene (C4H4Se) were well-treated via SQC/MM dynamics at the density functional level of electronic structure theory. In all cases, the SQC/MM approach appeared to be a reasonable alternative to what would otherwise be infeasible exact quantum calculations for these electronically nonadiabatic systems. 

As a final phase of this grant, attention was turned to the theoretical treatment of ruthenium polypyridyl complexes, which are candidate materials for increasing solar energy cell efficiency through dye-sensitization. It was shown that metal-to-ligand charge transfer states could be modeled at the density functional level of theory to reasonably match the experimentally-measured absorption band structure if the effect of spin-orbit coupling between singlet and triplet states was taken into account. Although there was insufficient time and computational resources during this grant period for a dynamics simulation of charge transfer in these dyes, doing so via the SQC/MM approach, including the nonadiabatic singlet/triplet state dynamics, is one potentially very interesting avenue for future work.
